title: Claude: Evaluation and Management of Vestibular Problems and Tinnitus Following Head Trauma
chief_complaint: I have a strange sensation of dizziness that isn't quite spinning when I move my head, but I get intense brief vertigo when I lie down or turn over in bed. My eyes don't seem to keep up with my head, and the ringing in my ears has gotten much worse since the accident.

problem_summary.onset: Symptoms began immediately following a motor vehicle accident (MVA) with head trauma.
problem_summary.course: Initial constant vertigo/nausea improved over 3 days to brief episodes. Tinnitus worsened post-accident. Imbalance persists.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss; Right vestibular involvement (BPPV and vestibulopathy).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Oscillopsia (blurred vision with head movement), imbalance in the dark, difficulty reading, sleep disturbance due to tinnitus.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Requires touching walls/furniture to ambulate, difficulty reading newspaper, trouble falling asleep.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to resolve dizziness, improve balance, and manage tinnitus.

history.present_illness: 71-year-old male post-MVA head trauma. Developed immediate constant vertigo/nausea/emesis, improving over 3 days. Now reports positional vertigo and general imbalance/oscillopsia.
history.otologic_history: No change in hearing status reported at hospital admission.
history.medical_psych_history: CT scan unremarkable. Treated with suppressants for 5 days post-MVA.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of dizziness and tinnitus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral, symmetric mild to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.key_findings: Tinnitus matched to 3 kHz tone. Residual inhibition observed (softer after 60s noise).

tests.name: Vestibular Evaluation (VNG/Calorics/Rotational)
tests.key_findings: Right unilateral weakness. Headshake elicited transient left-beating nystagmus. Oculomotor testing normal.

tests.name: Dix-Hallpike Maneuver
tests.key_findings: Positive for Right Posterior Canal BPPV. Intense vertigo and upbeating torsional nystagmus.

tests.name: Dynamic Visual Acuity (DVA)
tests.key_findings: Significant degradation with head movement, consistent with VOR impairment.

tests.name: Postural Stability
tests.key_findings: Fukuda stepping test showed right turn. Fall on dynamic surface with eyes closed (VSR impairment).

history.present_illness: Immediate treatment for BPPV following diagnosis.

tests.name: Canalith Repositioning (Gans Maneuver)
tests.key_findings: Gans Repositioning Maneuver (GRM) performed. After two maneuvers, no symptoms in provoking position.

history.present_illness: Follow-up to check BPPV status. Patient reported no vertigo but persistent dizziness with head movement.

tests.name: Positional Testing
tests.key_findings: Dix-Hallpike, side-lying, and deep head-hanging were all negative. VAST initially positive then negative (attributed to BPPV resolution).

history.present_illness: Completed 4 weeks of Vestibular Retraining Therapy (VRT) and hearing aid trial.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.key_findings: Significant improvement in dizziness handicap and tinnitus handicap.

tests.name: Postural Stability
tests.key_findings: Normal static stability; no falls on dynamic surface with eyes closed. Functional recovery of VSR.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presented with a mixed vestibular pathology following head trauma, including Right Posterior Canal BPPV and a right peripheral vestibulopathy (50% weakness) with associated VOR and VSR deficits. Audiometry revealed bilateral symmetric mild to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss. Following successful repositioning for BPPV, a course of VRT, and hearing aid fitting, the patient demonstrated functional compensation for the vestibulopathy and significant reduction in tinnitus perception.
counseling_points: BPPV Recurrence: There is a 5-30% chance the crystals may displace again. Contact us immediately if the spinning sensation returns.
VRT Expectations: Rehabilitation exercises may make you feel dizzier at first. This is normal and necessary for the brain to recalibrate.
Tinnitus Management: Hearing aids help by enriching your sound environment, making the tinnitus less noticeable. Avoid total silence.
Safety: Use nightlights and remove trip hazards at home, as your balance in the dark relies heavily on your inner ear.
